claim.text: the ADA specifies grab bars 33–36 inches above the floor
claim.claim: ADA specifies grab bars at 33-36 inches above the floor

results.summary: The ADA 2010 Standards Section 609.4 specifies grab bars shall be installed 33 inches minimum to 36 inches maximum above the finish floor, measured to the top of the gripping surface.
results.detail: According to the 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design, Section 609.4 (Height), grab bars must be installed in a horizontal position at 33 inches minimum and 36 inches maximum above the finish floor, measured to the top of the gripping surface. The claim accurately states this 33-36 inch range. Note: This verification is based on training data knowledge of the 2010 ADA Standards; web search was unavailable to confirm against current official sources.
sources: 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design, Section 609.4 (Height)

claim.text: ICC A117.1 requires bars on the side wall and rear wall of toilets, along the full length of bathtub walls, and in specific configurations in roll-in showers
claim.claim: ICC A117.1 requires grab bars on side wall and rear wall of toilets, along full length of bathtub walls, and in specific configurations in roll-in showers

results.summary: ICC A117.1 does require grab bars in these locations as described, though the specific configurations are detailed and technical.
results.detail: ICC A117.1 (Accessible and Usable Buildings and Facilities) is a real accessibility standard published by ICC. It does require grab bars on both the side wall and rear wall near water closets (toilets), grab bars along bathtub walls, and specific grab bar configurations for roll-in showers. The standard specifies dimensions, heights, and placement requirements. My confidence is 0.85 rather than higher because I cannot verify the exact current edition's specific wording without web access, though the general requirements described align with known accessibility standards.
sources: ICC A117.1 standard (general knowledge of accessibility codes)
ADA Standards for Accessible Design which references similar requirements

claim.text: A grab bar must support 250 pounds of force applied at any angle
claim.claim: Grab bars must support 250 pounds of force applied at any angle

results.summary: The 250-pound force requirement for grab bars is accurate per ADA Standards Section 609.8.
results.detail: The 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design, Section 609.8, specifies that grab bars shall be designed to resist a force of 250 pounds concentrated at any point. This requirement applies regardless of the angle at which force is applied, ensuring safety for users who may apply force in various directions during transfers or support.
sources: 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design, Section 609.8

claim.text: The cost of a hip fracture from a bathroom fall averages over $30,000 in medical expenses
claim.claim: Average medical cost of a hip fracture exceeds $30,000

results.summary: The claim that hip fracture costs exceed $30,000 is generally supported by medical literature, though estimates vary significantly.
results.detail: Multiple studies and healthcare analyses have found hip fracture costs in the range of $30,000-$50,000+ when including hospitalization, surgery, and initial rehabilitation. However, total costs vary considerably based on whether the estimate includes only acute care ($25,000-$35,000), post-acute rehabilitation ($10,000-$20,000 additional), or long-term care needs which can push total costs much higher. The CDC and other sources have cited figures in this range, though the specific '$30,000' threshold is a reasonable approximation rather than a precise figure. Unable to verify with live web search due to permission restrictions.
sources: Unable to access live sources - based on training data including CDC fall statistics, healthcare cost studies, and medical literature through early 2025

claim.text: for adults over 65, a hip fracture carries a 20–30 percent mortality rate within one year
claim.claim: Hip fracture mortality rate for adults over 65 is 20-30% within one year

results.summary: The 20-30% one-year mortality rate for hip fractures in adults over 65 is a well-established and widely cited statistic in medical literature.
results.detail: Multiple systematic reviews and large cohort studies confirm one-year mortality rates of approximately 20-30% following hip fracture in elderly patients. A 2010 systematic review in Osteoporosis International reported a pooled one-year mortality rate of approximately 25%. The Journal of Bone and Mineral Research and other orthopedic/geriatric journals have consistently reported figures in this range. Some studies show variation by age subgroup, sex, and comorbidities, but 20-30% is an accurate general figure for the 65+ population.
sources: Medical literature training data including Osteoporosis International systematic reviews
Journal of Bone and Mineral Research cohort studies
American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons guidelines
